abstract.text: A task your app performs in response to a notification that the system delivers.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: objects to define the actions that your app can perform in response to a delivered notification. You define the actions that your app supports. For example, a meeting app might define actions for accepting or rejecting a meeting invitation. The action object itself contains the title to display in an action button and the button’s appearance. After creating action objects, add them to a
object and register your categories with the system.

When someone performs a Double Tap gesture while viewing a notification on Apple Watch Series 9 or Apple Watch Ultra 2, the system invokes the first nondestructive action. A nondestructive action doesn’t include the
option, and won’t delete user data or change the app irrevocably.
For information on how to define actions and categories, see

content.text: Responding to the Selection of Actions

inlineContent.text: When the user selects one of your actions in response to a notification, the system notifies the delegate of the shared
object. Specifically, the system calls the
method of your delegate object. The response object passed to your delegate includes the
string of the action the user selects, which you can use to perform the corresponding task.
For information on how to handle actions, see

UserNotifications-PageImage-card.png.alt: [A notification interface displayed on the lock screen of an iOS device.]

abstract.text: Push user-facing notifications to the user’s device from a server, or generate them locally from your app.
A task your app performs in response to a notification that the system delivers.
The icon associated with the action.
The unique string that your app uses to identify the action.
Creates an action object by using the specified title and options.
Creates an action object by using the specified title, options, and icon.
The behaviors associated with the action.
The localized string to use as the title of the action.
The action has the default behavior.
The behaviors you can apply to an action.
The action performs a destructive task.
A type of notification your app supports and the custom actions that the system displays.
An action that accepts user-typed text.
The central object for managing notification-related activities for your app or app extension.
Asks the delegate to process the user’s response to a delivered notification.
Differentiate your notifications and add action buttons to the notification interface.
Respond to user interactions with the system’s notification interfaces, including handling your app’s custom actions.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
